text: Donald Trump has been elected president of the United States, a stunning upset for an outsider who defied the political establishment
President-elect Donald Trump is about to give his victory speech. Watch live as he addresses the nation he will soon lead.
Donald Trump said Hillary Clinton congratulated him on his win. "We owe her a major debt of gratitude," he said, calling for national unity.
Markets have slumped since Donald Trump's victory. His win raises questions about the world's financial underpinnings.
Hillary Clinton will address her supporters in New York shortly. Watch her speech and follow our live coverage.
“Donald Trump is going to be our president,” Hillary Clinton told the nation. “We owe him an open mind and a chance to lead.”
In a live address, President Obama pledged to help Donald Trump in his transition, saying “We are all rooting for his success”
Gov. Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, has unseated Senator Kelly Ayotte in New Hampshire. Republicans hold the Senate majority, 51-48.
President Obama and Donald Trump met at the White House. Mr. Trump called their 90-minute discussion a "great honor."
Leonard Cohen, whose musical career spanned nearly 50 years, has died at 82. "Hallelujah" may prove his most enduring song.
Vice President-elect Mike Pence is taking over the Trump transition from Chris Christie, whose standing fell in the bridge scandal
Hillary Clinton cast blame for her loss on a decision by James B. Comey, the F.B.I. chief, to revive an email inquiry ahead of the election
Donald Trump is expected to name Reince Priebus as his chief of staff, turning to a Washington insider for the critical role
Gwen Ifill has died at 61. She was a pioneering journalist who anchored PBS "NewsHour" and moderated presidential debates.
A police officer in St. Paul, Minn., faces manslaughter charges in the killing of Philando Castile. The aftermath was caught on video.
Donald Trump has offered Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn the post of national security adviser, according to a top transition official
Donald Trump has offered Jeff Sessions the post of attorney general. The Alabama senator was a close, early adviser to Mr. Trump.
Donald Trump has chosen Mike Pompeo to lead the C.I.A. He was a sharp critic of Hillary Clinton on the Benghazi committee.
The Zika virus is no longer a global emergency, said the World Health Organization, but it emphasized that the crisis is not over
Donald Trump has reached a $25 million settlement over accusations that Trump University cheated its students out of money
New doping tests on athletes who competed in the 2008 and 2012 Summer Olympics have uncovered scores of violations.
Donald Trump won't pursue investigations of Hillary Clinton when he becomes president, a top aide said
Donald Trump is at The New York Times for an on-the-record interview with our journalists. Get live updates.
In a Times interview, Donald Trump retreated from criticism of Hillary Clinton and climate deals. But he defended his business ties.
Donald Trump chose Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina as ambassador to the United Nations. She was an early critic of his run.
Florence Henderson, who made a lasting impression as the perky 1970s sitcom mom on "The Brady Bunch," has died at 82
Fidel Castro has died at 90. The Cuban revolutionary was a nemesis to 11 American presidents.
A plane carrying 81 people, including members of a Brazilian soccer club, crashed in Colombia. There are as many as six survivors.
Donald Trump’s Treasury secretary pick is said to be Steven Mnuchin, a financier with Hollywood ties but no government experience
Donald Trump made an Indiana factory a symbol of his economic plans. Now, he says he has a deal to save over 1,000 jobs there.
The officer in a fatal parking lot shooting in Charlotte, N.C., "acted lawfully" and will not be charged, the prosecutor said
Colombia's Congress approved a peace agreement with the country's largest rebel group in what was likely the deal's final hurdle
President François Hollande will not run for a second term. His approval ratings are among the worst in modern French history.
Donald Trump said his defense secretary pick is James Mattis, an ex-general with a tough stance on Iran and support in Congress
Donald Trump’s supporters filed legal challenges to presidential election recounts in Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan
Donald Trump spoke with Taiwan’s leader, breaking with decades of diplomatic practice. It could lead to a major rift with China.
The death toll rose to 24 in the Oakland, Calif., warehouse fire. Officials say it could take days to search through the rubble.
Austrians reject far-right candidate in presidential vote, stalling the advance of populist forces in Europe.
In a victory for protesters, the Army Corps of Engineers says it will look for alternative routes for the Dakota Access pipeline
Italians have rejected constitutional changes, dealing a blow to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and unsettling an already shaky E.U.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will visit Pearl Harbor. No Japanese leader has ever visited the site of the attack.
A mistrial was declared in the case of a North Charleston, S.C., police officer who shot an unarmed black man in the back in 2015
Saudi Arabia backs Afghanistan’s government, but the kingdom has long turned a blind eye to Saudis who bankroll the Taliban
John F. Kelly, a retired general whose son was killed in combat, is Donald Trump's choice to lead the department of homeland security
Donald Trump has selected Scott Pruitt, the Oklahoma attorney general and a close ally of the fossil fuel industry, to run the E.P.A.
Donald Trump is expected to pick the fast-food executive Andrew Puzder as labor secretary. He is against raising the minimum wage.
John Glenn has died at 95. A hero of the space age, he was the first American to orbit Earth, and later served in the Senate.
South Korea’s Parliament voted to impeach President Park Geun-hye over a corruption scandal. She will be suspended from office.
A new report by the world’s antidoping watchdog has laid out mountainous proof of Russia’s systematic doping program
President Obama has ordered intelligence agencies to produce a full report on Russian efforts to influence the 2016 election
U.S. intelligence agencies have "high confidence" Russia acted covertly to help Donald Trump in the election, officials said
Rex Tillerson, the Exxon Mobil chief with ties to Vladimir Putin, is expected to be Donald Trump's pick for secretary of state
Senator Mitch McConnell said he supported congressional investigations of possible Russian cyberattacks to influence the election
Donald Trump will name Rex Tillerson as secretary of state, dismissing concerns the Exxon chief is too cozy with Vladimir Putin
Donald Trump will pick Rick Perry as energy secretary. While running for president in 2012, Mr. Perry proposed scrapping the department.
The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for just the second time since the 2008 crisis, citing steady economic growth
Over 1 billion Yahoo accounts were hacked in 2013, the company said. Among the stolen data were passwords and security questions.
Dylann Roof, the white supremacist who shot nine black parishioners in Charleston, S.C., has been found guilty on all counts
For his envoy to Israel, Donald Trump has chosen a supporter of West Bank settlements who has insulted left-leaning American Jews
Hillary Clinton called Russia's hacking an “attack against our country” prompted by Vladimir Putin's "personal beef" against her
The Pentagon has demanded that China return an underwater drone seized by its warship in open waters in the South China Sea
President Obama defended his restrained response to hacking before the election but says he warned Russia, "We can do stuff to you"
Beijing agreed to return a drone seized in international waters, the Pentagon said. The incident elevated U.S.-China tensions.
Dr. Henry Heimlich is dead at 96. He developed and championed an anti-choking technique that saved an estimated 100,000 lives.
Zsa Zsa Gabor has died. Married eight times and with a modest acting career, she was famous for being famous. She was thought to be 99.
The chief of the I.M.F. has been convicted of criminal charges. Christine Lagarde may be forced from her post and faces jail time.
A gunman shot at the Russian ambassador to Turkey in Ankara, seriously wounding him, Turkish news media reported
Russia said its ambassador to Turkey has died, and called his killer a terrorist. Video shows the man saying, “Don't forget Syria!”
A truck drove into a Christmas market in Berlin, killing 9 people and injuring several others. The police believe it was an attack.
The Electoral College met and officially gave Donald Trump over 270 electoral votes, with scant evidence of a revolt among electors
A man held in the German truck attack was freed for lack of evidence. ISIS has claimed responsibility, and the culprit is at large.
President Obama has banned drilling in wide areas of the Atlantic and Arctic, a move he said could not be reversed by a successor
North Carolina failed to repeal a state law limiting gay and transgender rights that has prompted economic boycotts and lawsuits
In a turning point in the Syrian war, the government has taken full control of Aleppo after the last evacuation of rebel-held areas
The Tunisian man suspected in the attack at a Christmas market in Berlin has been fatally shot outside Milan, the police said
Money is pouring into immunotherapy research for cancer. But most of the patients who get into experimental trials are white.
The U.S. abstained in a U.N. vote against Israel’s settlement policy, defying calls to veto from Israel and Donald Trump
George Michael, an icon of pop music who infused social commentary with a dance-club beat, has died. He was 53.
Carrie Fisher is dead at 60. She won overnight fame as Princess Leia, a damsel who could deal with her own distress.
Russian officials admitted to The Times that they carried out widespread Olympic doping, saying it was an "institutional conspiracy"
John Kerry harshly rebuked Israel over its settlements, saying the U.S. couldn't allow "a two-state solution to be destroyed"
Debbie Reynolds has died at 84, a day after the death of her daughter, Carrie Fisher. Her best-known role was in "Singin' in the Rain."
Russia, Syria and Turkey announced a cease-fire for Syria. It wasn't immediately clear who was speaking for the rebels.
President Obama imposed sanctions on Russia, the strongest U.S. response to foreign hacking. The move could box in Donald Trump.
Donald Trump responded to Russian sanctions by reiterating his call to “move on.” But he pledged to meet with intelligence officials.
Russia is retaliating a day after the U.S. announced sanctions. Moscow plans to expel 35 American diplomats as part of its response.
Vladimir Putin won't expel 35 U.S. diplomats, as his foreign minister urged, apparently betting on better ties under Donald Trump
China plans to ban all commerce in ivory by the end of 2017. The move could deal a major blow to elephant poaching in Africa.
At least 35 were killed and dozens wounded in a terrorist attack at a packed Istanbul nightclub
House Republicans voted to gut the congressional ethics office, set up after corruption scandals. The move was made without notice.
Donald Trump rebuked House Republicans, saying there were more important things to do than “weakening" the independent ethics office
House Republicans reversed course and withdrew a plan to gut an ethics office, after intense criticism from Donald Trump and others
Fox News is losing its star anchor Megyn Kelly. She will move to NBC, where she will have her own daytime and weekend shows.
Dan Coats, a former senator, is Donald Trump's pick for national intelligence chief, a job some in his team see as superfluous
Donald Trump, in an interview with The Times, called the storm around Russian hacking before the election "a political witch hunt”
A shooting at the airport in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., left a number of people dead, the sheriff said. One person is in custody.
Donald Trump, after an intelligence briefing, conceded that Russia was among the possible culprits in the hacking of the D.N.C.
Vladimir Putin “ordered an influence campaign” aimed at helping Donald Trump win, a declassified intelligence report concludes
Ali Akbar Hashemi-Rafsanjani, former president of Iran, dies at 82
At the Golden Globes, "La La Land" had a record night, “Moonlight" won for drama and Meryl Streep forcefully criticized Donald Trump
Donald Trump will name his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, to a senior White House role. The move could test anti-nepotism laws.
In a wild second half, Clemson scored with 1 second left to stun Alabama, 35-31, and claim college football's national title
Fox News secretly settled sexual harassment claims against Bill O’Reilly shortly after Roger Ailes was ousted, documents show
The attorney general nominee Jeff Sessions said that waterboarding is illegal and that he opposes banning Muslims from the U.S.
Donald Trump wants Republicans to repeal the Affordable Care Act immediately and replace it "shortly thereafter," he told The Times
A jury has sentenced Dylann Roof to die. The white supremacist showed no remorse for killing 9 at a black church in South Carolina.
Intelligence chiefs told President Obama and Donald Trump of unsubstantiated reports that Russia had salacious information on Mr. Trump
In his last major turn on the national stage, President Obama is expected to stress unity. Watch live video of his Chicago speech.
Donald Trump will turn over business operations to a trust run by his sons and an associate, but won’t divest himself of his empire
How did the unverified stories on Donald Trump emerge? Look to the hidden side of presidential campaigns, and their sleuths-for-hire.
The Senate has taken a major step toward repealing the Affordable Care Act, paving the way for legislation to dismantle the law
The E.P.A. accused Fiat Chrysler of cheating on emissions tests on 100,000 diesel vehicles, a case with echoes of the VW scandal
The F.B.I. chief James Comey is facing an internal investigation into his pre-election actions on the Clinton email case
President Obama is ending a policy that allows Cubans who reach U.S. soil to stay legally, a move long sought by Cuba
The Chicago police have systemically violated civil rights, says a scathing Justice Department report following a 13-month inquiry
The House joined the Senate in taking a major step toward repealing Obamacare, adding urgency to the question of what comes next
After a 146-year run, Ringling Bros. circus will fold its tent for good in May. Tickets sales fell after it phased out elephants.
South Korea is seeking to arrest the head of Samsung for his role in the corruption scandal that led to the president's impeachment
The wife of the Orlando nightclub gunman has been arrested by the F.B.I. and charged with obstruction of justice
A suspect has been arrested in relation to the New Year's shooting that left 39 dead in an Istanbul nightclub, Turkish media said
Gene Cernan, the astronaut known for his daring and the last man to walk on the moon, has died. He was 82.
Britain's leader, in a major speech, backed a clean break from the E.U., its single market and its court system
18 million would lose insurance and premiums would soar in 2018 if Obamacare is partially repealed, a congressional study says
Nigeria mistakenly bombed a refugee camp while hunting militants. Doctors Without Borders counted 50 people dead and 120 injured.
Chelsea Manning, the ex-Army analyst who gave files to WikiLeaks, will be freed in May. President Obama is commuting her sentence.
The Earth hit a temperature record for the third year in a row, confirming that "we’re undergoing big changes,” a top scientist said
The Mexican drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, a master of escape known as El Chapo, has been extradited to the United States
U.S. intelligence agencies are examining intercepted communications and data for links between Donald Trump's associates and Russia
Donald Trump is now meeting with the Obamas at the White House; he’ll be sworn in around 11:45 Eastern. Get live video and analysis.
Donald John Trump has placed his hand on two Bibles and taken the oath of office. He is now the 45th president of the United States.
Protesters in Washington smashed windows and lit fires, and clashed with police trying to disperse them. At least 95 were arrested.
President Trump's first policy action was an executive order targeting Obamacare, acting on his pledge to eviscerate the law
Amid mass protests nationwide, President Trump and his spokesman accused the media of understating the turnout for his inauguration
President Trump has declared that the U.S. won’t join the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a sweeping trade pact negotiated by Barack Obama
Speaking to lawmakers, President Trump again falsely claimed that illegal immigrants had cost him the popular vote
President Trump plans to keep James B. Comey as director of the F.B.I. The agency is investigating Mr. Trump's associates.
The Oscar nominations included two records: “La La Land” got 14 nods, a tie for the most ever, and 6 black actors were nominated
Emboldened by President Trump, Israel approved 2,500 new settlement homes in the West Bank in a defiant wave of construction
President Trump is reviving the Keystone XL pipeline, which President Obama had blocked after opposition by environmental groups
President Trump is ordering construction of a Mexican wall, and may unveil plans to curtail immigration from "terror prone" nations
Mary Tyler Moore is dead at 80. She starred in one of the most popular TV shows ever and helped define a new vision of womanhood.
Mexico’s president canceled a visit with President Trump, as tensions rose over his insistence that Mexico pay for a border wall
President Trump's strategist Stephen Bannon attacked the media as the "opposition" and said it should "keep its mouth shut"
President Trump has proposed a 20 percent tax on all Mexican imports to pay for the border wall, his spokesman said
President Trump's temporary ban on refugees establishes a religious test: Christians from Muslim  nations will be given priority
Refugees have been stopped and detained at U.S. airports under President Trump's immigration ban, prompting legal action
A federal judge stayed part of President Trump's immigration order, barring refugees stopped at U.S. airports from being sent back
One U.S. commando was killed and four were hurt in President Trump’s first counterterrorism offensive, an attack in Yemen
After protests, the Trump administration seemed to scale back the president's immigration ban, but confusion continued
Gunmen killed five people at a mosque in Quebec City after they opened fire during evening prayers, the mosque's president said
The acting attorney general, an Obama holdover, has ordered the Justice Department not to defend President Trump's immigration order
Paving the way for transgender scouts, the Boy Scouts of America will accept members based on the gender listed on their application
President Trump has fired the acting attorney general after she told Justice Dept. lawyers not to defend his immigration ban
Neil Gorsuch is President Trump’s Supreme Court pick. The federal judge resembles Antonin Scalia in both philosophy and style.
The Senate confirmed Rex Tillerson as secretary of state. The narrow vote was among the most contentious for that role in recent history.
President Trump said he would "totally destroy" limits on political activity by tax-exempt churches. Congress would have to act.
President Trump unexpectedly shifted his stance on Israel, warning Prime Minister Netanyahu to hold off on settlement construction
President Trump is embracing key aspects of Barack Obama's strategy, refusing to lift sanctions on Russia and imposing new ones on Iran
President Trump and Republican lawmakers have begun an assault on financial regulation. Democrats called it a gift to Wall Street.
President Trump’s order led the U.S. to revoke most visas from 7 countries — officially about 60,000, though a lawyer said more
President Trump’s pick for Army secretary, Vincent Viola, dropped out. The billionaire Wall St. trader cited business conflicts.
Airlines were allowing formerly barred passengers to fly after a federal judge blocked President Trump's immigration order nationwide
The Trump administration moved to appeal a ruling blocking its immigration order just as the nation began opening its doors again
An appeals court has rejected the Trump administration's request to immediately reinstate its immigration order
The New England Patriots are champs again, erasing a 25-point deficit to beat Atlanta, 34-28, in the first Super Bowl to go to overtime
The Justice Department urged an appeals court to reinstate President Trump's travel ban, saying national security depends on it
Betsy DeVos has been confirmed as education secretary — barely. The vice president had to break a tie, a first for a cabinet pick.
An appeals court is about to hear arguments on President Trump’s immigration ban. Tune in live and get analysis from Times reporters.
An appellate panel expressed skepticism over Justice Dept. arguments in favor of President Trump's targeted travel ban
The Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch called President Trump’s attack on federal judges “demoralizing” and “disheartening”
Jeff Sessions has been confirmed as attorney general, a day after a Senate flare-up over Elizabeth Warren’s criticism of his record
President Trump’s travel ban remains blocked: An appeals court rejected a bid to reinstate it. An appeal to the Supreme Court is likely.
Is the president of China giving President Trump the silent treatment? Some officials think so, citing Mr. Trump's early provocations.
In a phone call, President Trump told President Xi Jinping that he endorses the "One China" policy, after months of silence and tension
Al Jarreau has died at 76. The versatile singer won seven Grammy Awards for his work in pop, R&B and his first love, jazz.
Adele tearfully accepted album of the year at the Grammys, and sets by Beyoncé and A Tribe Called Quest were the talk of the show
Michael Flynn, the national security adviser, is said to have misled senior officials about his conversation with a Russian diplomat
Michael Flynn is said to have resigned as President Trump's national security adviser, facing accusations about his dealings with Russia
President Trump faces a new test: Russia has secretly deployed a cruise missile that violates a crucial arms treaty, officials say
The nearly 40-year case of Etan Patz, the first missing child shown on a milk carton, is solved. An ex-deli worker was convicted.
President Trump knew for weeks that Michael Flynn wasn’t truthful about his Russian calls, his spokesman said, leading to his firing
The F.B.I. questioned Michael Flynn early in his tenure about his calls with Russia, officials said, raising the stakes of the scandal
Intercepted calls show members of the Trump campaign had repeated contact with Russian intelligence before the election, officials said
President Trump said he “can live with” a one-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, bucking decades of U.S. policy
President Trump’s pick for labor secretary, Andrew Puzder, has withdrawn amid doubts that he’d have enough votes to be confirmed
A seasoned legal opponent of the E.P.A. will now run it. Scott Pruitt was confirmed after Senate Democrats' all-night protest.
The anonymous plaintiff in Roe v. Wade has died. Norma McCorvey was a symbol of abortion rights, but reversed her views later in life.
Omar Abdel Rahman, the blind Islamic cleric found guilty of a 1993 plot to wage "a war of urban terrorism" in the U.S., has died
Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, a widely respected military strategist, has been named President Trump's national security adviser
The Trump administration detailed its new immigration policy, which greatly expands the categories of people subject to deportation
Seven newly identified planets orbiting a nearby star offer a realistic chance to seek signs of life beyond the solar system
The Trump administration has rescinded protections for transgender students that allowed them to use bathrooms of their choice
A banned chemical weapon, VX nerve agent, was used to kill the half-brother of North Korea’s dictator, the Malaysian police said
In a defeat for Bill Cosby, a judge ruled that a second woman who says he sexually assaulted her can testify at his trial
Journalists from several organizations, including The Times, were kept from attending a briefing by President Trump’s press secretary
Democrats elected former Labor Secretary Thomas Perez as party chairman over Keith Ellison, a liberal from Minnesota
President Trump’s budget outline calls for a surge in military spending and sharp cuts to nondefense agencies, including the E.P.A.
Talk about a Hollywood ending. "Moonlight" won the Oscar for best picture, but only after "La La Land" was mistakenly named the winner.
President Trump signaled a drastic shift, saying he is open to a plan to grant legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants
President Trump is about to address a joint session of Congress for the first time. Join us for live video and analysis.
President Trump stuck to the script, and G.O.P. orthodoxy, in a speech to Congress that laid out a broad agenda but few specifics
In their final days, Obama aides spread intelligence on Trump associates and Russia across agencies as a trail for investigators
Two House G.O.P. leaders urged the attorney general to recuse himself from an inquiry into Russian contacts with the Trump campaign
President Trump said he had “total” confidence in his attorney general and wasn't aware of his contacts with Russia's ambassador
The attorney general recused himself from any inquiry on Trump aides' Russian ties after his talks with the ambassador were revealed
Janet Yellen says the Fed will raise interest rates this month, earlier than expected, barring economic surprises
Uber has for years used its app to secretly identify and sidestep law enforcement officials where it was restricted or banned
The U.S. has tried to sabotage North Korea's missile program with covert cyber attacks. President Trump must decide what to do next.
President Trump demanded a congressional inquiry into whether Barack Obama tapped his phones. He still offered no proof for the charge.
The F.B.I. chief asked Justice officials to reject President Trump’s claim that Barack Obama tapped his phones. But the agency has not.
The Supreme Court has vacated an appeals court ruling in favor of a transgender boy in light of a move by the Trump administration
The Supreme Court ruled that confidential jury deliberations must be disclosed if there's evidence of racial bias by jurors
President Trump issued a more limited executive order on immigration. The changes are meant to help it withstand a court challenge.
The Republican replacement for Obamacare scraps mandated insurance in favor of incentives for people to buy it on the open market
WikiLeaks released what appeared to be C.I.A. documents about hacking programs used to break into phones, computers and TVs
A South Korean court has removed President Park Geun-hye from office, a decision that could reshape the strategic landscape in Asia
The U.S. economy grew by 235,000 jobs last month, paving the way for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next week
U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara is refusing to resign, forcing a potential showdown with President Trump and the Justice Department
Preet Bharara, the powerful U.S. attorney in Manhattan who refused to resign, has been fired
24 million would lose insurance under the G.O.P. health bill within a decade, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office found
President Trump made a rare disclosure about his finances. He paid $38 million in federal taxes on income of $150 million in 2005.
The U.S. charged 2 Russian spies and 2 others in a 2014 breach of 500 million Yahoo accounts that included the theft of personal data
The Fed raised interest rates for the third time since the financial crisis. We’ll be covering Janet Yellen’s news conference live.
The Republican leader of House Intelligence Committee cast doubt on President Trump’s claim that he was wiretapped
President Trump will detail his budget plan Thursday, with some severe cuts: 28% for the State Department and 31% for the E.P.A.
A federal judge in Hawaii has ruled against President Trump's revised travel ban, issuing a nationwide order to block it
In a test of European populism, Geert Wilders's anti-Islam party gained seats, but a big majority of Dutch voters rejected his views
The U.S. secretary of state said a freeze of North Korea's nuclear program was not enough and warned of pre-emptive action
President Trump's aides tried to soothe angry leaders in Britain after suggesting their spies wiretapped Trump Tower
The Nobel laureate Derek Walcott is dead at 87. His poetry captured the beauty of the Caribbean and the harsh legacy of colonialism.
President Trump stood by his wiretapping claim at a news conference with Angela Merkel. Pressed on it, he responded with a joke.
Chuck Berry, whose distinctive guitar licks, duckwalks and songs about girls and cars helped define rock 'n' roll, has died at 90
The F.B.I. is investigating Russia’s meddling in the U.S. election and its links with the Trump campaign, the agency’s director said
"I have no information that supports those tweets," the F.B.I. director said of President Trump's charge that Barack Obama wiretapped him
The U.S. has barred devices larger than a cellphone on American-bound foreign flights from 8 majority-Muslim countries
President Trump is poised to dismantle Barack Obama's climate policies. But his plan is certain to face legal pushback.
A shooting was reported near the British Parliament. The police evacuated the area.
An assailant at Britain’s Parliament was shot by the police after stabbing an officer. The complex remains on lockdown.
A vehicle hit five people on a bridge near the U.K. Parliament, killing one. It’s unclear whether the stabbing suspect was the driver.
At least 3 people were killed and 20 injured in the U.K. attack, officials said. The suspect also died after being shot by the police.
The Taliban have captured the strategic Afghan district of Sangin. It is the culmination of a deadly offensive that lasted years.
"We are not afraid," Theresa May said a day after the London attack. She said the assailant was U.K.-born and known to intelligence.
An Israeli-American teenager is suspected of calling in bomb threats against Jewish community centers across the U.S.
A British man, Khalid Masood, 52, carried out yesterday's attack in London, the police said. ISIS has claimed responsibility.
House Republicans postponed a vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act as President Trump and his allies struggled to win enough backers

Hosni Mubarak, the former Egyptian president who was ousted in 2011, is free after a long effort to hold him accountable for rights abuses
The Trump administration said it would issue a permit for construction of the long-disputed Keystone oil pipeline
Paul Ryan rushed to the White House to tell President Trump he does not have the votes to pass the repeal of Obamacare
President Trump suffered a major setback in the bid to repeal Obamacare: House Republicans, facing internal revolt, pulled their bill
Moments after the health bill was pulled, President Trump told The Times that he blamed Democrats, not Paul Ryan, for its failure
Up to 200 civilians were reported killed by recent American airstrikes in Mosul, Iraq. The military says it’s investigating.
Senate investigators will question Jared Kushner as part of a broad inquiry into ties between Trump associates and Russian officials
President Trump, flanked by coal miners and touting energy independence, signed an order to undo President Obama's climate legacy
With a hand-delivered letter, Britain has officially initiated "Brexit." The long divorce is likely to be littered with pitfalls.
Ivanka Trump will take an unpaid federal job as her father's assistant after her voluntary role raised ethics concerns
North Carolina lawmakers say they have reached a deal to repeal the so-called bathroom bill. The vote is scheduled for Thursday.
President Trump called a conservative faction in the House a threat to the Republican agenda, and vowed to “fight them” in 2018
Two White House officials helped provide intelligence reports about surveillance to the Republican leading the House Russia inquiry
A repeal of North Carolina’s “bathroom bill” was sent to the governor. He’s expected to sign it despite criticism of the compromise.
South Korea's ex-president Park Geun-hye was arrested and jailed after her impeachment on bribery and abuse of power charges
Ethics filings show Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner are worth at much as $741 million, and she has kept a stake in Washington's Trump Hotel
The artist James Rosenquist has died at 83. His boldly painted montages of commercial imagery helped define Pop Art in the 1960s.
Yevgeny Yevtushenko, an acclaimed poet whose defiant verse inspired a generation of Russians in their fight against Stalinism, has died
The University of South Carolina has claimed its first women’s basketball title with a 67-55 victory over Mississippi State
Explosions at two subway stations in St. Petersburg killed at least 10 people, Russia’s state-run news agency reported
Senate Democrats now have the votes to filibuster Neil Gorsuch, but the G.O.P. can change the rules to confirm him to the Supreme Court
Attorney General Jeff Sessions ordered a broad review of police agency agreements, including those that address abuses, as in Baltimore

Dozens were killed in Syria's worst chemical attack in years. The White House called it "reprehensible" and blamed Syria's president.
President Trump removed Stephen Bannon from a top National Security Council post in a move driven by his national security adviser
President Trump, in an interview with The Times, said Susan Rice may have committed a crime, and he defended Bill O’Reilly
The embattled House Intelligence Committee chief, Devin Nunes, will step aside from an inquiry on Trump aides’ ties to Russia

Republicans changed Senate rules to bar filibusters of Supreme Court nominees, seeking to bypass Democrats’ blockade of Neil Gorsuch
Autopsies of victims of the chemical attack in Syria indicate the banned nerve agent sarin was used, Turkey said
Don Rickles, the acidic stand-up comic, has died at 90. His insults flew at everyone, from Frank Sinatra to his own audiences.

President Trump said it was in the "vital national security interest" of the U.S. to prevent the spread of deadly chemical weapons
The U.S. economy added only 98,000 jobs in March, suggesting a cooling of the economy after months of strong job growth

Two explosions in Egypt killed dozens of worshipers at Coptic churches on Palm Sunday. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.
Sergio García won the Masters in a playoff, finally taking his first major 18 years after he burst on the scene as a teenage prodigy
